levels.title: Info
levels.content:
# Demo Summary

The demo contains all types of levels to demonstrate the training capabilities of the KYPO Cyber Range Platform.

| Level | Level Name | Level Type |
|:------:|------| ------ |
| 1. | Info | Info |
| 2. | Finding Open Ports | Game |
| 3. | Connecting via Telnet | Game |
| 4. | Privilege Escalation | Game |
| 5. | Test Example | Assessment |
| 6. | Assessment Example | Assessment |

## Info

The level contains this information page.

## Finding open ports

The level provides information on how to connect to a sandbox. In general, there are two possible approaches. The first approach is to use the platform'a GUI to connect to the machine via Spice console. The second approach is to connect through SSH with a generated config file and keys.

This level's small challenge is to scan open ports.

## Connecting Via Telnet

This level's challenge is to connect to the server machine without a password and discover the secret flag.

## Privilege Escalation

This demo's bigger challenge is to gain root privileges and read a flag available only to a root user. Enjoy! 

## Test Example

The level contains a simple example of a test. Tests can be used, for example, for additional testing of students for grading purposes.

## Assessment Example

The level contains a simple example of a test. For example, the tests can be used to verify the learning outcomes or for collecting feedback.

levels.title: Finding open ports
levels.content:
Your goal is to get access to a **server**. You know that there is a **telnet** service running on the server but it is not running on the default port. Your first task is to find the **port** on which the telnet service is running. The flag is the port number.

Below are two options how to connect to the client from which you can connect to the server.

## GUI access
1. In the topology overview, click the button in the top-right corner of the graph, then **`Expand All`**, **`client`** and **`Generate console URL`**. After a few moments, **`Open link`** next to the **`Generate console URL`** should appear.

2. Login using username **`kypo`** and password **`kypo`**.

## SSH from local machine
1. Use the **`Get SSH Access`** button to download **`ssh-access.zip`**.

2. Extract the **`ssh-access.zip`** file to your **`~/.ssh/`** directory.

    `$ unzip ssh-access.zip -d ~/.ssh/`

3. Execute the extracted source script in the current shell using the **`source`** command with the path to the KYPO proxy SSH private key. The source script that will set the **`ssh`** command and the **KYPO proxy SSH private key**, which is available from instance operator.

    `$ source ~/.ssh/pool-id-<pool_ID>-sandbox-id-<sbx_ID>-user-source.sh PATH_TO_KYPO_PROXY_PRIVATE_KEY`

4. Connect to the client to **`kypo`** user. 

    `$ ssh kypo@client`
levels.solution:
1. Connect to the client using either of the options.

2. Look for open ports using the command **`nmap server`**. You can see **ssh** running on port **22** and some other service running on port **2323**. This has to be the **telnet** service.

3. Enter **`2323`** as the flag.

hints.title: Tool to find open ports
hints.content: A common tool to find open ports is **nmap**. You can learn how to use nmap using **`nmap --help`** or by searching online.

levels.title: Connecting via Telnet
levels.content: Now you have the port number and you would like to connect, but you don't have any credentials. Luckily you know that user **`alice`** has a weak password. You might be able to guess it. The flag is in alices home directory. There is a list of common passwords placed in your home directory for your convenience.
levels.solution:
1. You know that **alice** has a weak password so you can try a dictionary attack. A list of common passwords is ready in your home directory. One of possible tools to make a password attack is **hydra**. A command to find the password is **`hydra -l alice -P passlist.txt telnet://server:2323`**. This will reveal alices password **`bacon`**.

2. Now you can connect to the server by using **`telnet server 2323`**, entering username **`alice`** and her password **`bacon`**.

3. To read the flag you can use **`cat flag.txt`**.

hints.title: Connecting using telnet
hints.content: The command to connect using telnet is **`telnet <host> <port>`**, so in our case **`telnet server 2323`**. You will be prompted to enter an username and password.

hints.title: Tool for password attacks
hints.content: Common tools for password attacks are **hydra** and **medusa**. Consult their help commands or man pages to find appropriate options to perform the attack. You can use the list of common passwords stored in your home directory. Use ls to list files.

levels.title: Privilege Escalation
levels.content: Great, you managed to login to the server as **alice** but there is not much you can do as **alice**. Can you find a way to become **root**? The flag is in roots home directory.
levels.solution:
1. One of common privilege escalation attack vectors is badly configured **sudo**. To see what you can use sudo for, use the **`sudo --list`** command.

2. You can see that the only command you can use sudo on is **`less /home/alice/flag.txt`**. There is not much to see in the flag, but you can run this as **root**. Is there a way to get a shell?

3. There is, all you have to do is enter **`!sh`** while running the **`sudo less /home/alice/flag.txt`** to get a root shell.

4. To get the flag, use **`cd`** to enter roots home directory and **`cat flag.txt`** to read the flag.

hints.title: Attack vector
hints.content: One of common privilege escalation attack vectors is badly configured **sudo**. To see what you can use sudo for, use the **`sudo --list`** command.

hints.title: Using the privilege escalation
hints.content: You have probably figured out that you can run **sudo** on a certain **less** command. To get a shell enter **`!sh`** while running the **less** command.
